comments:
Criminology 370 examines criminality from an interdisciplinary perspective. Incorporating psychology, neuroscience, sociology, anthropology, law, forensics, and other readings, the course explores various influences on criminality while also analyzing controversial ethical, legal, and philosophical issues of criminality. Broadly, the course will help students understand, predict, and prevent criminal behavior.

The majority of students enjoyed the course content. Several students described the course materials and content as “extremely interesting” and praised the organization of the course. Multiple students appreciated the course’s field trip as particularly useful and enlightening.

Most students were enthusiastic about Professor Raine. Students described Professor Raine as “well-versed in the literature of the field” and “an excellent lecturer.” Students also appreciated that Professor Raine was “fair in his exams and expectations” and “seemed genuinely interested in getting to know all of the students.”

This course seemed to attract a range of students from different class years and majors. Most students found the coursework fair and tested for fairly. Many students recommended the class for both majors and non-majors.
